tit.cmt: すぐ下に説明があるためここはタイトルのみとしました。

sen.j: 品官（ほんかん）とは、日本の律令制において各官司の四等官の体系に属しない官職の総称を指す。
sen.e: Honkan was a general term of government posts which did not belong to the system for shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks) of each government official in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code [historical law system]) of Japan.

Honkan was a general term of government posts which did not belong to the system for shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks) of each government official in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code [historical law system]) of Japan.

Honkan was a general term of government posts which did not belong to the system for shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks) of each government official in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code [historical law system]) of Japan.

sen.j: 中国の律令制にも「品官」と呼ばれる官職群は存在するが、この場合従九品以上の官品に属する全ての官職（日本で言う職事官）を指すものであり、日本の品官の名称そのものは中国のそれに由来しているものの、意味合いが全く違うものである（ただし、日本においても職事官の意味での「品官」という語も用いられていたという説がある）。
sen.e: Chinese ritsuryo system also had a government post called 'honkan' but in this case, it meant all government posts (it was called shikijikan [a person with an official rank but has no corresponding position] in Japan) which belonged to kanhin (governmental officials classified into nine grades from first honkan to ninth honkan) of over Junior Ninth Rank and honkan in Japan had a completely different definition although the name was derived from Chinese honkan. (However, it is said that 'honkan' was also used in the sense of shikijikan in Japan)

sen.cmt: 複数化、動詞変更、ピリオドの位置変更
sen.e: Chinese ritsuryo system also had a government post called 'honkan' but in this case, it meant all government posts (they were equivalent to shikijikan [a person with an official rank but has no corresponding position] in Japan) which belonged to kanhin (governmental officials classified into nine grades from first honkan to ninth honkan) of over Junior Ninth Rank and honkan in Japan had a completely different definition although the name was derived from Chinese honkan (However, it is said that 'honkan' was also used in the sense of shikijikan in Japan).

sen.j: 日本の品官は組織上はどこかの官司に属しているものの、四等官とは別に専門性の高い職掌を有した別局を構成し、かつ官位令において官位相当が定められているものである。
sen.e: Honkan in Japan systemically belonged to some government officials but also constituted another bureau with highly-official duties apart from shitokan and the kanisoto (the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system) was provided by Court ranking law.

Honkan in Japan systemically belonged to some government officials but also constituted Bekkyoku which performed technical official duties apart from shitokan and the kanisoto (the ranks of the bureaucracy system under the ritsuryo system) was provided by Court ranking law.
sen.cmt: 「専門性」訳抜け、繰り返しの回避、「別局」は全文から判断するに「another bureau」ではなく固有名詞かと思われるので「Bekkyoku」としました。
sen.e: Honkan in Japan systemically belonged to some government officials but also constituted Bekkyoku which performed technical official duties apart from shitokan and the kanisoto (the ranks of the bureaucracy system under the ritsuryo system) was provided by Court ranking law.

sen.j: 代表的な品官としては中務省に属する侍従や内記・監物、刑部省に属する判事 (律令制)などが挙げられる。
sen.e: The representative honkan included jiju (Imperial Household Agency staff), naiki (secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs), kenmotsu (a auditor Nakatsukasa sho, the Ministry of Civil Affairs) who were belonged to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs), a judge (in the ritsuryo system) who belonged to Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) and so on.

The representative honkan included jiju (Imperial Household Agency staff), naiki (secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs), and kenmotsu (a auditor Nakatsukasa sho, the Ministry of Civil Affairs), who were belonged to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs), a judge (in the ritsuryo system) who belonged to Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) and so on.

The representative honkan included jiju (Imperial Household Agency staff), naiki (secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs), and kenmotsu (a auditor Nakatsukasa sho, the Ministry of Civil Affairs), who were belonged to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs), a judge (in the ritsuryo system) who belonged to Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) and so on.

sen.j: 中国の律令制にも別局は存在するものの、官司を統括する「長官」と通判を行う「次官」の指揮下に別局を統括する「判官」が置かれているという三判制の原則があり、また検勾制による監督を受けていたが、日本の四等官と品官の間にはそのような関係は存在しなかった。
sen.e: Chinese ritsuryo system also had another bureau but had a policy of sanhansei (system which a final decision was made by 'kami' [a director], suke [undersecretary] and hangan [a judge]) which 'hangan' who controlled the another bureau was placed under the command of 'kami' (a director) who controlled government officials and 'suke' who performed tsuhan (a an official supporting a governor), and was subject to supervision by kenkosei (system to inspect management), however, shitokan and honkan in Japan were not in such a relationship.
sen.cmt: 「三判制」 →正確な読み、定訳不明「検勾制」→正確な読み、定訳不明
sen.e: Chinese ritsuryo system also had Bekkyoku but had a policy of sanhansei which 'hangan' who controlled Bekkyoku was placed under the command of 'kami' (a director) who controlled government officials and 'suke' who played a part of tsuhan (an official supporting a governor), and was supervised by kenkosei (system to inspect management), however, shitokan and honkan in Japan were not in such a relationship.
sen.cmt: 三判制は本文中に説明があるため、括弧内での補足は必要ないと判断し、削除しました。文の簡略化、「a」削除、括弧内の補足に合うよう、動詞の変更、「別局」は全文から判断するに「another bureau」ではなく固有名詞かと思われるので「Bekkyoku」としました。
sen.e: Chinese ritsuryo system also had Bekkyoku but had a policy of sanhansei which 'hangan' who controlled Bekkyoku was placed under the command of 'kami' (a director) who controlled government officials and 'suke' who played a part of tsuhan (an official supporting a governor), and was supervised by kenkosei (system to inspect management), however, shitokan and honkan in Japan were not in such a relationship.

sen.j: これは日本の律令制が省・職・司・寮それぞれに一定の独立性を持たせたこと、加えて律令制以前に存在していた独立していた官司（監物・判事など）を従来の独立性を維持させたまま、強引に特定の省の管轄に加えたために生じたとされ、特に朝廷内部の事務一般を管轄した中務省には多くの品官が集中することになった。
sen.e: It was because in Japanese ritsuryo system, each sho (Ministry), shiki (agency), tsukasa (office) and ryo (bureau) had a certain independence and, in addition, it is said that it arose since government officials (such as kenmotsu and a judge) which had existed before the ritsuryo system and been independent were forced to be added into the jurisdiction of a specific sho as having kept the traditional independence and as a result, many honkan gathered especially in the Nakatsukasasho which exercised jurisdiction over general affairs within the Imperial Court.

It was because in Japanese ritsuryo system, each sho (Ministry), shiki (agency), tsukasa (office) and ryo (bureau) had a certain independence, in addition, it is said that it arose since government officials (such as kenmotsu and a judge) which had existed and been independent before the ritsuryo system were forced to be added into jurisdiction of a specific sho with keeping the traditional independence, and as a result, many honkan gathered especially in the Nakatsukasasho which took charge of general affairs within the Imperial Court.
